pageData.text: The surfaces of soil particles are constantly interacting with the soil in ways that affect plant growth and other ecosystem services. In the Soil Chemistry lab, you will estimate an important interaction called <button class='glossary-text'>sorption</button> and assess important properties of the soil solution that affect plant growth: pH, salinity and sodicity.

pageData.text: When soil gets infiltrated by salt, it affects the plants trying to grow there. Usually, salt makes it more challenging for the plants to grow and can even render the soil completely inhospitable to the plants that once flourished there. Salt can infiltrate the soil when aquifers are overdrawn or when coastal wetlands are destroyed, leading to seawater seeping into new environments. However, while most plants are harmed by salt, some plants, like mangroves, have evolved to grow in high salinity environments. Mangroves, which live in tropical salt marshes, have many adaptations which allow them to deal with the <button class='glossary-text'>osmotic stress</button> of high salt. Their roots have both barriers to inhibit salt uptake in the form of thick Casparian strips, and specialized glands which actively pump out salt when concentrations get too high. The genes which allow for these adaptations have been identified and some scientists are hoping to create transgenic species of rice and other food crops with these genes<sup>1</sup>. This might allow these plants to once again grow in areas where the soil has been damaged by salt infiltration.

1Somssich, M. (2020). How a mangrove tree can help to improve the salt tolerance of Arabidopsis and rice. Plant Physiology, 184 (4), 1630–1632.
https://doi.org/10.1104/pp.20.01370

pageData.subTitle: Sorption
pageData.text: of chemicals by soil particles is what enables soil to “hold onto” nutrients which can then be used by plants. Sorption in general is the retention of solutes (i.e., dissolved chemicals) by the soil solution, onto or into soil particles. There are two mechanisms by which sorption can occur (Figure 1). occurs when a solution moves into soil pore spaces, carrying solutes with it. Absorption tends to be greatest in soils with high proportions of micropores capable of absorbing the soil solution. Hence, soils with greater clay and organic matter content can absorb more solutes. occurs when solutes adhere onto the surfaces of particles and are largely influenced by chemical charge and pH. Adsorption is influenced by soil particle surface area, surface charges and surface polarity. These are also affected by soil clay content, but in a more complicated manner. In general, as soil clay content increases, surface area increases, and with more surfaces to adsorb to, adsorption tends to increase as well.

pageData.subTitle: Role of cations and charge in adsorption
pageData.text: Solutes are attracted to clay-sized particles, especially colloids (particles <0.001 mm), due to a combination of charge and polarity. In chemistry, opposite charges attract. Table salt (NaCl), for example, is comprised of oppositely charged ions: the cation Na<sup>+</sup> (sodium) has a positive charge, and the anion Cl<sup>-</sup> (chloride) has a negative charge. In table salt, Na<sup>+</sup> is attracted to Cl<sup>-</sup> because they are oppositely charged. Soil clay particles are predominately composed of layered silicate minerals that usually carry a negative surface charge. The charge originates predominately from oxygen atoms, which are <button class='glossary-text'>electronegative</button>, meaning they attract electrons (e<sup>-</sup>) from other atoms, and therefore tend to develop a negative charge. When the negative charge of the oxygen in a mineral is greater than the positive charges of cations (such as Al<sup>3+</sup>, Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Mn<sup>2+</sup>), an overall negative surface charge develops. The charge can be diffused (i.e., spread out over the whole surface), or localized to specific negatively charged oxygen on the surface, called <button class='glossary-text'>negative charge sites</button>. This negative surface charge, like Cl<sup>-</sup>, attracts cations like Na<sup>+</sup> from the soil solution.

Some clay minerals as well as soil organic matter have what is called or , or charge that changes with pH. Minerals that have significant pH-dependent charge include some layer clays, as well as Fe and Al oxides and hydroxides. These are highly weathered minerals, and hence tend to be more abundant in more weathered soils. Along with organic matter, the surface charges of these minerals go from positive at low pH to more negative at high pH. This occurs because as soil pH decreases, the concentration of H+ ions in the soil solution increases. These H+ then adsorb to so strongly that those sites develop an overall positive charge. This positive charge then attracts oppositely charged anions such as Cl+, NO3+ or SO4+ from the soil solution. As pH increases, the H+ concentration decreases, causing the sites to lose H+ and develop a negative charge instead (Figure 2). This negative charge attracts cations such as Ca+ and K+. As a result, soils with a significant amount of pH-dependent charge go from sorbing relatively more anions at low pH to relatively more cations at high pH.

pageData.subTitle: Ion Exchange
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Ion Exchange</button> is the rapid and reversible swapping of ions in the soil solution with ions absorbed on soil surfaces. In any soil, there are a limited number of exchange sites. Thus, any ions present that are not adsorbed to a particle remain in the soil solution.

<button class='glossary-text'>Adsorption</button> of the ions can occur 2 ways: through inner or outer sphere adsorption. In <button class='glossary-text'>inner-sphere adsorption</button>, ions bond directly to atoms on a particle’s surface. These bonds hold the ion very close to the surface and are strong enough that the ions cannot be easily replaced by other ions. This is how soil filters out heavy metals like lead (Pb) from water. In <button class='glossary-text'>outer-sphere adsorption</button>, a layer of water molecules persists between the surface and the ion, forming a bridge between them. For example, Ca<sup>2+</sup> can adhere to the oxygen in water (which has a partial negative charge), and then the H<sup>+</sup> in that water molecule (which is partially positively charged) would in turn adhere to the negatively charged oxygen on the particle surface.

There are two types of ion exchange, depending on the charge of the ion: 1) <button class='glossary-text'>cation exchange</button>, which is the rapid swapping of positively charged ions, and 2) <button class='glossary-text'>anion exchange</button>, which is the rapid swapping of negatively charged ions. Ca<sup>2</sup> swapping with Mg<sup>2+</sup> as described above and H<sup>+</sup> swapping with K<sup>+</sup> in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button> are examples of cation exchange. Several important plant macronutrients adsorb through these types of ion exchange, and are said to be “exchangeable”:

1. Exchangeable cation nutrients: NH4+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+
  2. Exchangeable anion nutrients: NO3-, SO42-

For plants to gain access to the above nutrient cations, they exude H+ and other acids from their roots, which replace nutrient cations on soil particles. This cation exchange process forces the nutrients back into the soil solution, where they are available for uptake by the plant (Figure 2). Indeed, plants can only get nutrients that are in the solution or exchangeable, as nutrients must be able to flow with or diffuse through water to get to the plant root and diffuse into its cells. Exchangeable anions are generally easily taken up by plants without much effort, as the positive charge of most soils is minimal. Some nutrients do not participate in exchange though, such as Fe3+ and H2PO4-, because they adsorb too strongly to be replaced by other ions.

The influence of pH and the presence of other ions in solution on <button class='glossary-text'>adsorption</button> makes it difficult to compare the effect of just the soil particles themselves on adsorption via exchange with ions being lower cased. Instead of measuring ions exchanged, the maximum number of ions that could be exchanged is measured. The maximum number of cations that could adsorb to soil via exchange is called the soil <button class='glossary-text'>cation exchange capacity (CEC)</button>, and the maximum number of anions that could adsorb to soil via exchange is the <button class='glossary-text'>anion exchange capacity (AEC)</button>. Hence, CEC is equal to the sum of negative soil surface charges, and AEC is equal to the sum of positive soil surface charges. CEC and AEC are different from adsorption because they represent the maximum potential for adsorption, whereas adsorption of any one cation or anion at any given time is likely to be well below the CEC or AEC, respectively.

Since most soils have a very low AEC, CEC is generally of greater interest. Displacement methods are the only way to directly quantify CEC or AEC total capacity. In the displacement method, a solution containing very high concentrations of a saturating cation is added to the soil. This saturating cation, no matter its charge, outnumbers other cations by such a vast amount that it replaces virtually all of the exchangeable cations in the soil. In this way, all of the exchange sites are filled, or saturated, with the saturating cation. Then a displacing cation is added, which displaces the saturating cation into the solution. This enables the ability to measure the concentration of the first saturating cation in the final solution, thus providing an assessment of the soil exchange capacity. In this investigation, you’ll use NH4+ as a saturating cation and K+ as a displacing cation, as shown in Figure 3.

pageData.subTitle: Effect of soil pH and cation exchange on plant growth
pageData.text: Although not equal, CEC and cation <button class='glossary-text'>sorption</button> are positively correlated with each other, as are AEC and anion sorption. Therefore, anything that increases cation sorption will increase CEC, and anything that increases anion sorption will also increase AEC. As a result, pH plays an important role in sorption capacity. As pH increases, the density of <button class='glossary-text'>negative charge sites</button> in soil increases, and CEC increases. Generally, more weathered soils have lower pH, so as weathering increases, pH decreases, and CEC decreases. More weathered soils such as tropical soils also have lower concentrations of some layered clays, further lowering their negative charge and CEC. This is the main reason why tropical rainforest soils aren’t very suitable for growing crops. On the other hand, temperate grassland soils experience moderate weathering and have moderate to high pH, resulting in high CEC and high fertilities.

Soil pH affects the overall amounts of plant-available nutrients, with extremes resulting in toxic levels of some nutrients and low availability in others (Figure 4). Only nutrients that are located in the soil solution or adsorbed to exchange sites are available to plants. Soil pH can impact solubility or exchange capacity of important plant nutrients, and this impacts the various cations differently. Nitrogen, potassium, and sulfur are important plant nutrients that are relatively stable across pH levels between 5.5 and 8. Phosphorus, however, precipitates with iron and aluminum in alkaline soils and with calcium and magnesium in acidic soils, making phosphorus unavailable for plants in both environments. Given these impacts on nutrient availability, a pH of 6.5 is optimum for growth of most plants.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cation exchange capacity (CEC) is the maximum amount of cations that can adsorb to a soil or other material. Positively charged nutrients - such as K<sup>+</sup>, Ca<sup>2+</sup> and NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> - are cations, therefore a soil with a greater CEC can adsorb more of these nutrients.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Clay and organic matter have very high surface areas and charge densities, therefore (assuming pH isn’t too low), they contribute to the vast majority of soil CEC.

pageData.subTitle: Salt-affected soils: salinity and sodicity
pageData.text: Soils that have excess total salts or an imbalance of cations to the point where plant growth is inhibited are called <button class='glossary-text'>salt-affected soils</button>. These soils are commonly found in dry ecosystems such as deserts, where rainfall is insufficient to wash salts away. Sources of salts include rocks, wind-blown dust, and irrigation water.

Soils with too much total salts are called <button class='glossary-text'>saline soil</button>. The salt concentrations in these soils are so high that they cause plants to undergo <button class='glossary-text'>osmotic stress</button>, wherein excess salts in soil slow or stop the flow of water into plant roots. The total water potential of a plant’s roots must be lower than that of the soil for water to flow into the roots through osmosis (because water always flows from high to low water potential). Thus, as salt concentration increases, osmotic potential decreases. In saline soils, salt concentrations are very high, lowering osmotic potential and therefore total soil water potential to the point where typical plants can’t keep their water potential lower than that of the soil.

Soils with an excess of sodium (Na) relative to other nonacid cations (Ca, Mg and K) are called <button class='glossary-text'>sodic soils</button> (“sod-” stands for “sodium”). These soils are actually less fertile than saline soils due to numerous detrimental impacts on soil physical and chemical properties. Sodium causes <button class='glossary-text'>dispersion</button> of clay particles, meaning that the clay particles separate from each other instead of flocculating, i.e., aggregating or sticking together. This is a problem because dispersed clays flow into pores when the soil is moist, then when the soil dries, they clog up the pores. Clogged pores lead to both reduced infiltration and drainage of water into and out of soil, respectively. After rain, clays in sodic soils frequently become dispersed in puddles on the surface of the soil, which then dry down and form hard crusts in a phenomenon called <button class='glossary-text'>crusting</button>.

Lastly, sodicity increases pH. Sodium increases the solubility of carbonates, because sodium carbonate (Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) is much more soluble than the more common calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>). As a result, increasing Na<sup>+</sup> in soil increases the amount of CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> in solution, which in turn increases the pH to 8.5 or higher. In addition to having poor structure, sodic soils are too alkaline to grow most plants.

In this investigation, you will measure several soil properties essential in nutrient availability for plants which include <button class='glossary-text'>sorption</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cation exchange</button>, salinity and sodicity.

Make sure that the soil is well mixed with the solution and that there are no air pockets in the soil. It may be necessary to gently tap on the glass vial or shake for another minute at a different angle.
Allow the soil sample to settle for at least 2–5 minutes.
Place the funnel on top of the cup labeled “Collected Soil”. Place a coffee filter inside the funnel. Wet the filter slightly so it will stick to the funnel.
Pour the soil sample carefully into the funnel.
After most of the water has filtered out of the funnel, remove the funnel and the soil sample.

Hold the cup up to Table 1 to check for excessive cloudiness. If you can see the cloudiness ranking line 2 through your filtrate sample, your sample is not excessively cloudy. Record your results in Data Table 1 and you can proceed to Step 16.

In Activity 2, you will examine <button class='glossary-text'>cation exchange</button> in soil by first adding an ammonium solution to the soil, then adding KCl to the soil and testing the resultant ammonium levels in the soil filtrate.
Label a cup “KCl” with a grease pencil or marker. This stands for potassium chloride.
Use the digital balance, spoon, and weigh boat to measure 1.5g of KCl. Pour it into the cup.
Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder, measure 100 mL of water. Add the water to the cup and stir until dissolved.
Label a clean cup “Control”.
Pour 4 mL of the of 6 ppm (NH4)2SO4 solution from Activity 1 into the “Control” cup.

Obtain a funnel and coffee filter. Open the coffee filter and place the filter in the funnel. Wet the filter slightly with water to get it to stick to the inside of the funnel. Place the funnel on top of the cup.
Use the digital scale and weigh boat to measure 15 g of sample. Pour the soil onto the filter paper.
Form a small depression in the center of the sample so that the liquid additions will go through the sample and not down the sides.
In this step, you will wash excess salts from the sample that may interfere with NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup> <button class='glossary-text'>adsorption</button>.

text: Using the 100 mL graduated cylinder, measure 30 mL of water of distilled or spring water.

Using the 100 mL graduated cylinder, measure 30 mL of the KCl solution, and pour it on top of the soil in the funnel. Wait until the water has stopped or nearly stopped dripping (or until you’ve collected about 4–5 mL).

Note: The potassium ions (K+) which have been added will replace to a large degree the NH4+ cations which were previously adsorbed by the soil. The replaced cations are then carried by the leaching solution into the filtrate.
Test the filtrate in the cup for NH4+ with an ammonium test strip (API Brand) from the equipment set. Allow the test strip to sit in the solution for 5 seconds.

In Activity 3, you will examine the sodicity and salinity of the soil by adding calcium chloride dihydride and NaCl to a suspension of soil particles in a soil solution.
Obtain 3 vials. Label the vials “Coarse Sand”, “Collected Soil” and “Sample Z”.
Use the digital scale and weigh boat to measure 7 g of coarse sand. Pour the soil onto the vial.
Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder and measure 20–25 mL of water.
Pour the water into the “Coarse Sand” vial and cover the top of the test tube with one of the pieces of cut Parafilm, and thoroughly mix.
Allow the soil sample to settle for 10–15 minutes.

Now you will test the effect of increasing salinity and sodicity together, instead of just sodicity. Add an additional 1/4 of a mini spoon of calcium chloride dihydrate (CaCl2 • 2H2O) to one of the samples you just tested for sodicity. Mix thoroughly.
Wait 10-15 min, and check for changes. Record your observations in Data Table 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample. In Activity 1, you will label the cup and prepare the ammonium solution. Then, you will dip the test strip, wait 60 seconds, and compare the color to the color chart. If the color does not match, you will add more ammonium. If it does match, you will label your test tubes and cups, and add the ammonium solution to the control. Then, you will measure the soil, add it to the tube, add the ammonium, cover the tube with parafilm, mix it, and let the tube sit. Next, you will filter the soil through the filter apparatus. If the sample is cloudy, you will wait 24 hours and then filter the sample again. When the filtrate is no longer cloudy, you will pour the filtrate into a test tube, test the filtrate with a test strip, and compare it to the color chart. When all samples have been tested, you will proceed to activity 2.

A map describing the procedural workflow of activities 2-3 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, label cups and prepare a KCl solution. Then, add a sample to the filter apparatus, pour water on it, and discard the filtrate. Next, pour ammonium solution on the sample. Then, pour water on it and discard the filtrate. Next, pour KCl solution on the sample. Then, test the filtrate, wait, and compare the color to the chart. Repeat for all samples. In activity 3, label the vials, measure the mass of the sample, add water, mix, and wait 10-15 minutes. If performing the salinity test, add CaCl2. If performing the sodicity test, add NaCl. If performing the combined test, add CaCl2 to the NaCl test vials. Then, wait 15 minutes and observe. If the suspension is unchanged, add more of the substance, wait, and observe. Repeat this until the suspension is changed. When all samples are tested, reset the vials and perform the other test on all samples.

data.title: Absorption
data.content: Occurs when solutions moves into soil pore spaces, carrying solutes with it

data.title: Adsorption
data.content: Occurs when solutes adhere to the surfaces of particles and are influenced by chemical charge and pH

data.title: Anion exchange
data.content: The rapid swapping of negatively charged ions

data.title: Anion exchange capacity (AEC)
data.content: The maximum number of anions that could adsorb to soil via exchange

data.title: Cation exchange
data.content: The rapid swapping of positively charged ions

data.title: Cation exchange capacity (CEC)
data.content: The maximum number of cations that could adsorb to soil via exchange

data.title: Crusting
data.content: A phenomenon in which clays in sodic soil dry out and create a hard crusty layer

data.title: Dispersion
data.content: Separation

data.title: Electronegative
data.content: Refers to an atom's ability to attract electrons from other atoms

data.title: Inner-sphere adsorption
data.content: Adsorption resulting from ions that bond directly to atoms on a particle's surface

data.title: Ion exchange
data.content: The rapid and reversible swapping of ions in the soil solutions with ions absorbed on soil surfaces

data.title: Negative charge site
data.content: A localized area of negative charge

data.title: Osmotic stress
data.content: A sudden change in solute concentration, wherein excess salts in soil stop or slow the flow of water to plant roots

data.title: Outer-sphere adsorption
data.content: Adsorption resulting from a layer of water molecules that act as a bridge between the ions and the surface

data.title: pH-dependent charge
data.content: A charge that changes with pH; also called a variable charge

data.title: Saline soil
data.content: Soil that has too much total salt

data.title: Salt-affected soil
data.content: Soil that has excess total salts or an imbalance of cations to the point where plant growth is inhibited

data.title: Sodic soil
data.content: Soil with excess sodium (Na) relative to other non-acid cations (Ca, Mg, and K)

data.title: Sorption
data.content: The retention of solutes (dissolved chemicals) by the soil solution

data.title: Variable charge
data.content: See "pH-dependent charge"
